source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Materials studied contained a range of impurity contents with iron ranging from 300 to 1500 ppm in both the cold-worked and cold-worked + annealed (24 h/560°C) conditions
composition_raw: Zr-2.5Nb with Fe 300-1500 ppm, Cr 50-160 ppm
process_step: hot extrusion at 850°C, cold-working (20-30%), autoclave stress-relief at 400°C for 24 h

extra_properties.microstructure: deformed α-Zr grains with β-Zr network (~20 wt% Nb) surrounding α-Zr grains
extra_properties.precipitates: Zr_2Fe (tetragonal) and Zr(FeCr)_2 (C-15 cubic or C-14 hexagonal Laves phase)
extra_properties.phase_transformation: β-Zr phase decomposes into α-Zr + β-Nb (~83 wt% Nb) + Zr(FeCr)_2 on annealing
extra_properties.fabrication_process: hot extrusion at 850°C, cold-working (20-30%), autoclave stress-relief at 400°C for 24 h

extra_properties.phase_composition: β-Nb particles contain approximately 83 wt% Nb, 1.5 wt% Fe or 1.3 wt% Cr

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Intermetallic precipitates were formed at the α-Zr grain boundaries along with the β-Nb in all heat-treated materials

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The Zr(FeCr)_2 precipitates with a cubic structure were found in heat-treated samples of tubes 185, D1162, and D1301

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Zr(FeCr)_2 precipitates with a hexagonal structure were also found in heat-treated tubes 185, D1162, and D1301

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: A third type of intermetallic precipitate was found in heat-treated samples of tube D1301. These precipitates were identified as the Zr_2Fe phase

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Tubes D168, D1345, D1260, D587 and C170 contain less than 729 ppm Fe and less than 80 ppm Cr. After annealing at 560°C for 24 h

extra_properties.precipitate_formation: small precipitates at α-β Zr grain boundaries

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: The microstructure of cold-worked $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ pressure tubing consists of elongated $\alpha - \mathrm { Z r }$ grains with a $\beta { - } Z \operatorname { r }$ $( \sim 2 0 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb) network at the $\mathbf { \alpha } \mathbf { - } \mathbf { } \mathbf { } \mathbf { } Z \mathbf { r }$ grain boundaries
composition_raw: Zr-2.5Nb, ~20 wt% Nb in β-Zr phase

extra_properties.microstructure: elongated α-Zr grains with β-Zr network at grain boundaries
extra_properties.precipitates: Zr₂Fe present in tubes with >500 ppm Fe
extra_properties.grain_size: larger α-Zr grain size promotes Zr₂Fe formation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: Heating of the as-fabricated, coldworked tubing for $2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ at $5 6 0 \%$ produced a breakdown of the $\beta$ -Zr ${ \sim } 2 0 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nbnetwork surrounding the elongated $\alpha$ -Zr grains to discrete particles of $\beta$ -Nb $\sim 8 3 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb)

extra_properties.microstructural_changes: β-Zr decomposes to β-Nb particles and Zr(FeCr)₂ Laves phase
extra_properties.reaction: β-Zr (∼20 wt% Nb) → α-Zr + β-Nb (∼83 wt% Nb) + Zr(FeCr)₂

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: If during reactor operation at ${ \sim } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ there is a breakdown of the ${ \beta } { \cdot } Z \tau$ phase to $\beta$ -Nb and the concurrent precipitation of $Z \mathrm { { r } ( F e C r ) _ { \vec { \tau } } }$ , the corrosion/hydriding resistance could be affected

extra_properties.potential_effects: Zr(FeCr)₂ precipitation may affect corrosion/hydriding resistance
extra_properties.irradiation_effects: irradiation produces different decomposition sequence than thermal treatment

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: X-ray map showing Nb and Fe distribution in as-fabricated Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: X-ray map showing Nb and Fe distribution in a Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube after heat treatment for 750 h at 500°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: EDX analysis showing Fe segregation in the β phase of an as-fabricated Zr2.5Nb pressure tube

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: EDX analysis showing Fe depletion from the β-phase of a Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube after irradiation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: Heat treatment sufficient to totally decompose the β-phase, for example 500°C for 750 h

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: Irradiation in a CANDU reactor results in dispersion of the Fe from the β-phase

extra_properties.irradiation_effects: Fe dispersion from β-phase, enhanced β-Nb precipitation from α-phase, suppressed β-phase decomposition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: Tubular samples of Zircaloy-4 clad, of the standard $1 7 \times 1 7$ PWR design, in the cold worked, stress relieved condition, with a mean wall thickness $\xi = 5 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ , and samples machined to reduce their wall thickness to 200 and $8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ , respectively
conditions: air at one bar pressure, temperatures 623-723 K, exposure periods up to 753 days

extra_properties.oxidation_model: ε_z/Δw = A·(ξ)^m where A and m vary with temperature
